sub_topic: Determining the chromatic number of a graph.
message_1:
What is the minimum number of colors needed to color the vertices of the following graph such that no two adjacent vertices are of the same color?

![Graph](https://i.imgur.com/lAsNYzL.png) 

(Hint: The chromatic number of a graph is the smallest number of colors needed to color the vertices of the graph.)
message_2:
To determine the chromatic number of this graph, we can use the greedy coloring algorithm. We start by assigning the first color to the first vertex, and then we move on to the next vertex. If it is adjacent to a vertex with the first color, we assign it the second color. We continue this process for all vertices in the graph.

1. Assign color 1 to vertex A.
2. Vertex B is adjacent to A, so assign color 2 to vertex B.
3. Vertex C is adjacent to A and B, so assign color 3 to vertex C.
4. Vertex D is adjacent to B and C, so assign color 1 to vertex D.
5. Vertex E is adjacent to A and D, so assign color 2 to vertex E.
6. Vertex F is adjacent to A, C, and E, so assign color 3 to vertex F.

We have used 3 colors to color the vertices of the graph such that no two adjacent vertices have the same color. Therefore, the chromatic number of this graph is 3.
